# 總裁報告

2016年的全球政經舞台上「黑天鵝」身影頻仍，英國脫歐公投和美國總統大選結果固然令各種民調淪為笑柄，但更出乎意料的卻是金融市場的反應。以美國大選為例，特朗普當選消息令美股三大指數的期貨在開市前急挫，但開市不久美股指數隨即反彈，此後凱歌高奏，屢創新高。連串事件，凸顯了傳統智慧和思維對預測市場能力的局限性，也標誌着未來環球局勢發展的重大不確定性。

過去一年，多項主要金融數據都反映市場情緒異常敏感：美國十年期國庫債券收益率在7月跌至1.36厘歷史低位後，在美國總統大選後的12月中旬飆升至2.6厘。反映美元兌一籃子貨幣走勢的美匯指數在年底升至14年高位；紐約原油期貨價格由年初每桶26美元低位反彈至年底的54美元。本港股市方面，恒生指數全年微升86點，但期內峰谷差逾6,000點。外圍形勢驚濤駭浪，更形金融體系尤其是貨幣和銀行體系穩定的重要和可貴。

2016年1月，國際對沖基金部署狙擊人民幣和港元的傳言甚囂塵上，人心虛怯。金管局迅即向市場發放明確、堅定的訊息，我們絕對有信心、有能力捍衛聯匯制度和香港的金融體系穩定，適時穩住了市場信心。綜觀2016年全年，港元長時間貼近強方兌換保證。由於銀行體系資金非常充裕，即使去年12月和今年3月美國聯儲局加息，對港元利率和匯率並未有明顯的即時影響。

香港銀行體系繼續穩步發展，去年整體貸款錄得6.5%溫和增長，資產質素保持良好，不良貸款比率維持在0.85%的健康水平，遠低於2000年以來約2%的長期平均水平。銀行體系的資本充足率和流動性比率均保持在高於法定要求的高水平。在樓宇按揭業務方面，經過七輪逆周期措施，新造住宅物業按揭平均成數從2009年9月的64%下降至2016年底的51%，平均供款與入息比率也從2010年8月的41%下降至2016年底的34%，為樓市周期一旦逆轉而令銀行體系受到衝擊時，提供了所需的緩衝。金管局會繼續密切留意樓市的發展，因應周期變化而採取合適措施，以保持銀行體系穩定。

進一步強化銀行體系穩定的立法工作去年取得令人鼓舞的進展。優化存款保障制度和針對金融機構「大得不能倒」風險的兩條法例，及時在上屆立法會任期屆滿前順利通過。前者加快存款保障金的發放速度，簡化發放程序，有助加強存戶對銀行體系的信心；後者則為包括銀行在內的金融機構建立處置機制，防範這些機構一旦倒閉而引發的系統性金融風險，並盡量避免動用公帑為它們「包底埋單」。金管局已在今年4月1日設立處置機制辦公室，落實執行法例的要求和跟進工作。

銀行業素有「百業之母」之稱，是實體經濟和普羅市民日常生活倚重的儲蓄、支付渠道和信貸來源。年內，部分中小企業界代表反映融資有困難。金管局即時與銀行界溝通，希望銀行在維持審慎風險管理的情況下，盡可能為中小企的營運和發展繼續提供資金支援。我們又透過轄下香港按揭證券公司，加強向工商界推廣政府的「中小企融資擔保計劃」，並與銀行業界緊密溝通，以釋除疑慮、釐清誤解及理順處理壞帳的索償程序，從而提高銀行參與該計劃的意願。多管齊下，收到了一定成效，根據金管局對銀行進行的調查，中小企整體信貸額度在去年保持平穩，超過九成企業的信貸額度得以維持甚至增加。同時，「中小企融資擔保計劃」的申請數字亦明顯上升。

近年來金管局大力推動普及金融，就是考慮到基本銀行服務已是營商和日常生活不可或缺的環節。去年當我們得知有些海外公司和初創企業在香港開戶遇到困難後，旋即展開跟進工作，與多個國際商會和企業協會聯繫，並跟銀行業界深入溝通，對症下藥。去年9月我向香港所有銀行簽發通告，闡釋應如何理解金管局針對反洗錢和恐怖分子資金籌集活動的「風險為本」監管原則，如何將這項原則應用在開戶申請和對現有客戶的盡職審查措施上，強調銀行不應對所有客戶採用「一刀切」的要求和程序。經我們與銀行和商界協商後，企業開戶情況有所改善，但仍有進步空間，這也是我們今年工作重點之一。

普及金融還涉及銀行分行服務的覆蓋面。金管局一直鼓勵銀行在營商圖利之餘，也要顧及市民的基本銀行服務需要。金融科技一日千里，銀行提供服務的渠道也更趨多元化。除了日益普及的網上銀行服務外，去年多家銀行紛紛推出流動銀行車或視像櫃員機服務，提供較傳統櫃員機更貼身、更全面的銀行服務。在我們的推動下，多家銀行也計劃在偏遠地區設立實體分行，加強對當區居民的服務。

金融中心的發展就如逆水行舟，因此，金管局多年來不斷為香港金融業發展尋求新的契機，開拓新的領域。2016年可說是成果豐碩的一年，當中又以金融科技(Fintech)和基建融資為亮點。

在金融科技方面，香港的零售支付服務在2016年進入新時代。金管局去年發出13個儲值支付工具牌照，通過發牌和恒常監管制度為零售支付服務創造有利的營商環境，配以一系列公眾教育宣傳，讓消費者在享受新科技帶來的便捷之餘，權益也得到合理保障。

此外，去年3月金管局成立了金融科技促進辦公室，以此平台推動與銀行業相關的金融科技發展。幾個月間，我們推出多項新猷，包括「網絡防衛計劃」(Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative)，為強化銀行體系網絡安全建立風險評估、資訊共享和人才培訓三足鼎立的新平台。我們並與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作，開展分布式分類帳技術(distributed ledger technology)專項研究，探討該技術在香港銀行業應用的可行性，並在應科院設立金融科技創新中心(Fintech Innovation Hub)，為銀行業界和金融科技界提供技術支援。金管局的銀行監管部門還設立「金融科技監管沙盒」(Fintech Supervisory Sandbox)，讓銀行在較小和可控範圍內測試新技術的應用，為新產品、新服務的開發提速。自去年9月至今年3月，已有6家銀行共14項新技術項目使用沙盒進行測試，部分項目亦已相繼推出市場，為市民帶來更多金融科技的新產品。

世界各地對基建融資的需求巨大，特別是「一帶一路」倡議提出以來，基建融資更成中外矚目的議題。香港是亞洲的國際金融中心，在基建融資領域極具優勢。去年7月金管局成立了基建融資促進辦公室(Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office，簡稱IFFO)，搭建一個嶄新和獨特的平台，匯聚60多家世界級的多邊機構、機構投資者、銀行、保險公司和其他金融機構、基建項目的建設和營運方、各類專業機構等，就基建投融資課題互通訊息、交流經驗、尋求合作機會。IFFO成立至今已舉辦十多場大型會議、研討會和工作坊，金管局並分別與國際金融公司(International Finance Corporation)、全球基礎設施中心(Global Infrastructure Hub)、國家開發銀行(China Development Bank)和中國進出口銀行(The Export-Import Bank of China)簽署了共同促進基建投融資活動的《諒解備忘錄》。起步時間雖然不長，但為香港未來作為基建投融資中心奠下堅實的基礎。

拆牆鬆綁是提升競爭力的不二法門。年內，金管局積極參與和支援特區政府修訂稅務條例，向在港經營集團內部財資業務的企業提供有利的稅務環境。我們並積極接觸跨國企業，吸引它們來港發展或擴充企業財資活動，藉此進一步強化香港金融市場的功能。

去年的離岸人民幣市場處於調整期。受市場波動和對人民幣匯率預期等因素影響，全球離岸人民幣資金池規模普遍收縮。儘管如此，香港仍穩執離岸人民幣業務的牛耳，保持全球最大的人民幣資金池，經香港結算的人民幣維持在日均約8,600億元人民幣高位。為進一步優化香港離岸人民幣市場的流動性安排，去年10月我們將一級流動性提供行由7家增至9家，支援雙邊流動資金的總額度由原來的140億元人民幣增至180億元，確保在離岸人民幣市場資金出現緊絀的情況下，仍可保持市場有序運作。去年12月股票市場「深港通」開通，令香港的人民幣業務再添動力。金管局亦正與內地有關當局研究「債券通」方案，進一步便利兩地投資者參與債券市場，並優化債券市場基礎設施的聯繫。

儘管去年全球投資環境充斥着各種不穩因素，但有賴於過去一段時間所採取的多項防禦性部署，外匯基金去年錄得681億港元投資收入。自1994年以來外匯基金的複合年度投資回報率達4.8%，高於同期2.1%的本地通脹率。

外匯基金將繼續推動多元化投資，包括進一步擴展資產類別，加大對於信貸資產、抵禦通脹類投資產品和新興市場的投資。而作為多元化投資旗艦的「長期增長組合」，透過私募股權和房地產項目等投資於另類資產。該組合自2009年啟動以來一直保持不俗的成績，成立至今的平均內部回報率年率約12%，而隨着政府「未來基金」部分投放於該組合，我們加快了投資步伐，去年底「長期增長組合」的資產規模約1,818億港元，已批出但未提取作投資的總額約1,338億港元。外匯基金將繼續恪守「保本先行、長期增值」的投資策略，在保持充裕的流動性和備用資金的前提下，尋求長遠穩定的回報。

# CEO Report

In 2016, the global political and economic stage was frequently marked by the appearance of "black swan" events. Although the UK's Brexit referendum and the outcome of the US presidential election rendered various polls a laughing stock, more surprisingly was the reaction of financial markets. Taking the US election as an example, news of Trump's election led to an immediate plunge in the three major US stock indices' futures before market opening. However, shortly after the market opened, the US stock indices quickly rebounded, thereafter trending upward and repeatedly setting new highs. This series of events highlighted the limitations of traditional wisdom and thinking in predicting market capabilities, also marking a milestone in the major uncertainties of future global developments.

Over the past year, multiple key financial data points have reflected exceptionally sensitive market sentiment: the yield on US 10-year Treasury bonds fell to a historical low of 1.36 basis points in July, then surged to 2.6 basis points by mid-December following the US presidential election. The US Dollar Index, which reflects the movement of the US dollar against a basket of currencies, rose to a 14-year high by year-end; New York crude oil futures prices rebounded from a year-start low of $26 per barrel to $54 by year-end. In Hong Kong's stock market, the Hang Seng Index mildly rose by 86 points for the year, although the peak-to-trough difference during the period exceeded 6,000 points. With turbulent external conditions, the importance and value of financial system stability, particularly in the monetary and banking systems, have become even more evident.

In January 2016, rumors that international hedge funds were plotting to target the renminbi and Hong Kong dollar were rampant, causing public anxiety. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority promptly disseminated clear and resolute messages to the market, emphasizing that we have absolute confidence and capability to defend the linked exchange rate system and ensure the stability of Hong Kong's financial system, timely stabilizing market confidence. Throughout 2016, the Hong Kong dollar remained closely aligned with the strong-side exchange rate guarantee for an extended period. Due to ample liquidity in the banking system, even though the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates in December 2016 and March 2017, there was no immediate significant impact on the Hong Kong dollar's interest rates or exchange rates.

The Hong Kong banking system has continued to develop steadily. Overall loans recorded a modest growth of 6.5% last year, with asset quality remaining good and the non-performing loan ratio maintained at a healthy level of 0.85%, well below the long-term average of about 2% since 2000. The banking system's capital adequacy ratio and liquidity ratio have both remained at high levels above statutory requirements. In the residential mortgage business, after seven rounds of counter-cyclical measures, the average loan-to-value (LTV) ratio for newly granted residential property mortgages declined from 64% in September 2009 to 51% by the end of 2016. The average debt-to-income ratio also fell from 41% in August 2010 to 34% by the end of 2016, providing the necessary buffer should the property market cycle reverse and impact the banking system. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will continue to closely monitor the development of the property market and take appropriate measures in response to cyclical changes to maintain banking system stability.

Legislative efforts to further strengthen the stability of the banking system made encouraging progress last year. Two pieces of legislation, aimed at optimizing the deposit protection scheme and addressing the risks associated with the "too big to fail" nature of financial institutions, were smoothly passed in a timely manner before the previous Legislative Council term ended. The former accelerates the payout of deposit protection funds and simplifies the payout process, helping to enhance depositors' confidence in the banking system; the latter establishes a resolution mechanism for financial institutions, including banks, to prevent systemic financial risks arising from their failure and to minimize the need to use public funds to bail them out. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has established a Resolution Mechanism Office since April 1, 2023, to implement the requirements of the legislation and oversee follow-up work.

The banking sector is known as the "mother of all industries" and serves as a vital channel for savings, payments, and credit for the real economy and the general public's daily lives. During the year, some representatives from the SME sector reported difficulties in financing. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) immediately communicated with the banking sector, hoping that banks would continue to provide funding support to SMEs' operations and development while maintaining prudent risk management. We also strengthened the promotion of the government's "SME Financing Guarantee Scheme" to the business community through our subsidiary, the Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation Limited, and maintained close communication with the banking sector to alleviate concerns, clarify misunderstandings, and streamline the claims process for bad debts, thereby increasing banks' willingness to participate in the program. Through these multi-pronged measures, certain results have been achieved. According to a survey conducted by the HKMA, the overall credit facilities for SMEs remained stable last year, with credit limits maintained or even increased for over 90% of companies. Meanwhile, the number of applications for the "SME Financing Guarantee Scheme" also rose significantly.

In recent years, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has vigorously promoted financial inclusion, recognizing that basic banking services have become an essential component of business operations and daily life. Last year, after learning that some overseas companies and startups encountered difficulties in opening accounts in Hong Kong, we immediately initiated follow-up efforts, contacting multiple international chambers of commerce and industry associations, and engaging in in-depth communication with the banking sector to implement targeted measures. In September last year, I issued a notice to all Hong Kong banks, explaining how to understand the HKMA's "risk-based" regulatory principles concerning anti-money laundering and the financing of terrorist activities, and how to apply these principles to account opening applications and due diligence measures for existing customers. I emphasized that banks should not adopt a "one-size-fits-all" approach for all customers. After consultations with banks and the business community, the situation regarding company account openings has improved, but there is still room for further progress, which remains one of our key priorities this year.

Financial inclusion also involves the coverage of bank branch services. The HKMA has consistently encouraged banks, while pursuing commercial profits, to also take into account the public's basic banking service needs. As fintech advances rapidly, the channels through which banks provide services are also becoming more diversified. In addition to the increasingly popular online banking services, several banks launched mobile banking units or video teller machine services last year, offering more personalized and comprehensive banking services than traditional ATMs. Under our promotion, several banks have also planned to establish physical branches in remote areas to enhance services for local residents.

The development of a financial centre is like rowing upstream, and therefore, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been continuously seeking new opportunities for the development of Hong Kong's financial industry and exploring new areas over the years. 2016 was a fruitful year, with fintech and infrastructure financing standing out as highlights.

In the field of fintech, Hong Kong's retail payment services entered a new era in 2016. Last year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued 13 stored value payment facilities licenses, creating a conducive business environment for retail payment services through licensing and a regulatory regime, accompanied by a series of public education campaigns, ensuring that consumers enjoy the convenience brought by new technology while their rights are properly protected.

In addition, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Fintech Facilitation Office in March last year to promote the development of fintech related to the banking sector. Within a few months, we launched several new initiatives, including the "Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative," establishing a new three-pronged platform for risk assessment, information sharing, and talent training to strengthen the cybersecurity of the banking system. We also collaborated with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) to conduct specialized research on distributed ledger technology, exploring the feasibility of its application in Hong Kong's banking sector, and established the Fintech Innovation Hub at ASTRI to provide technical support to the banking sector and fintech industry. The HKMA's banking supervisory department also set up the "Fintech Supervisory Sandbox," allowing banks to test new technologies in a smaller and controlled environment, accelerating the development of new products and services. From September last year to March this year, six banks have tested 14 new technology projects using the sandbox, with some projects already launched in the market, bringing more fintech products to the public.

The global demand for infrastructure financing is substantial, especially since the proposal of the Belt and Road Initiative, making infrastructure financing a focal topic of interest both domestically and internationally. As Asia's international financial center, Hong Kong holds significant advantages in the field of infrastructure financing. In July last year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office, abbreviated as IFFO), creating a new and unique platform to bring together over 60 world-class multilateral institutions, institutional investors, banks, insurance companies, and other financial institutions, as well as developers and operators of infrastructure projects and various professional institutions, to exchange information, share experiences, and seek cooperation opportunities regarding infrastructure investment and financing. Since its establishment, IFFO has organized more than ten large-scale conferences, seminars, and workshops. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also signed Memorandums of Understanding with the International Finance Corporation, the Global Infrastructure Hub, the China Development Bank, and the Export-Import Bank of China to jointly promote infrastructure investment and financing activities. Although its operational period is relatively short, it has laid a solid foundation for Hong Kong's future role as a center for infrastructure investment and financing.

Breaking down barriers is the surest way to enhance competitiveness. This year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has actively participated in and supported the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government in amending the Inland Revenue Ordinance, providing a favorable tax environment for enterprises operating internal treasury business within the group in Hong Kong. We have also actively engaged with multinational corporations, attracting them to develop or expand their corporate treasury activities in Hong Kong, thereby further strengthening the functions of Hong Kong's financial market.

Last year's offshore RMB market was in an adjustment period. Affected by factors such as market volatility and expectations regarding the RMB exchange rate, the scale of global offshore RMB funding pools generally contracted. Despite this, Hong Kong still maintains a leading position in offshore RMB business, sustaining the world's largest RMB funding pool, with RMB settled through Hong Kong remaining at a daily average high of approximately RMB86 billion. To further optimize liquidity arrangements in Hong Kong's offshore RMB market, in October last year we increased the number of primary liquidity providers from 7 to 9, raising the total quota for bilateral liquidity funding from RMB14 billion to RMB18 billion, ensuring that even in the event of tightening in the offshore RMB market, the market can maintain orderly operations. The launch of the Shenzhen-Hong Kong Connect in December last year further boosted Hong Kong's RMB business. The HKMA is also working with relevant mainland authorities to study the Bond Connect framework, further facilitating participation of investors from both sides in the bond market and optimizing the linkage of bond market infrastructure.

Despite the global investment environment being fraught with various unstable factors last year, the Foreign Exchange Fund recorded an investment income of 681 billion Hong Kong dollars, thanks to the multiple defensive measures taken over the past period. Since 1994, the Foreign Exchange Fund's compound annual investment return rate has reached 4.8%, higher than the 2.1% local inflation rate during the same period.

The Exchange Fund will continue to promote diversified investments, including further expanding asset categories and increasing allocations to credit assets, inflation-protected investment products, and emerging markets. As the flagship of diversified investments, the "Long-Term Growth Portfolio" invests in alternative assets through private equity and real estate projects. Since its launch in 2009, the portfolio has maintained strong performance, achieving an average annualised internal rate of return of approximately 12% since establishment. With the government's "Future Fund" partially allocated to this portfolio, we have accelerated our investment pace. As of the end of last year, the asset size of the "Long-Term Growth Portfolio" amounted to approximately HK$181.8 billion, with a total amount of approximately HK$133.8 billion approved but not yet drawn down for investment. The Exchange Fund will continue to adhere to the investment strategy of "capital preservation first, long-term value growth," seeking long-term stable returns while maintaining ample liquidity and contingency funds.

# 2016 Highlights

# economic and financial environment

With subdued global economic and trade activities, Hong Kong's economic growth has softened. Hong Kong's stock market and residential property market have experienced volatility this year, and housing affordability remains stretched.

Despite the increase in global market risks and shocks, Hong Kong's banking system remains sound. Bank capital and liquidity conditions remain good; asset quality shows slight signs of deterioration, but remains at healthy levels.

# Currency Stability

Despite facing a volatile external environment, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remains stable, reflecting the resilience of the linked exchange rate system to withstand external shocks.

Money markets continue to operate smoothly, with ample interbank liquidity. In December, following the Federal Reserve's decision to raise the Federal Funds Rate target range, Hong Kong's basic interest rate was increased by 25 basis points to 1.00%.

# Banking System Stability

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority strengthens the regulatory risk governance framework, as well as the management of credit, liquidity, and technology risks. The HKMA also takes specific actions to promote financial inclusion and address the difficulties companies encounter when opening and maintaining bank accounts in Hong Kong.

In terms of regulatory policy, significant progress has been made in Hong Kong's preparations for implementing international regulatory and accounting standards, including the resolution framework under the Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance.

# Hong Kong's International Financial Centre Status

Hong Kong maintains its position as the global offshore Renminbi business hub and asset management centre. The tax system has been further refined to foster a more favorable environment, attracting multinational companies to establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong.

To develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing centre and a fintech hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office. The HKMA smoothly commenced the implementation of the regulatory regime for stored value payment tools and retail payment systems, and granted 13 stored value payment tools licences.

# Reserve Management

Despite the difficult investment environment, which was full of black swan events, thanks to a series of defensive measures taken over the past few years that enhanced the foreign exchange fund's resilience, the fund recorded a 2% overall investment return.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority quickens the pace of diversification of investment, especially in long-term growth portfolios.

# Institutional Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority communicates effectively with the community and market through media, public education activities, and other various channels, facilitating the public's understanding of the Authority's policies and operations.

The HKMA continues to strengthen institutional governance, including supporting staff in enhancing their professional capabilities, strict financial control, and enhanced IT security measures, to help cope with the challenges brought about by implementing new measures and increasingly complex tasks.

廣東省（包括深圳）與香港之間的電子支票聯合結算啟動。

在政府債券計劃下發行首批銀色債券。

# 9月

# 9月6日

# 2016 Calendar of Events

# 1 January

# January 14

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announces that the counter-cyclical buffer capital ratio applicable to Hong Kong will be adjusted upwards to 1.25% with effect from January 1, 2017.

# February

# 5 February

The HKMA and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) published conclusions to the proposals on introducing mandatory clearing and expanding mandatory reporting in the regulatory regime for OTC derivatives.

# March

#21 March

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Fintech Facilitation Office to promote Hong Kong as a fintech hub in Asia.

# May

# 16 May

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announces the extension of the Coin Collection programme for another two years until September 2018.

# May 18th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced at the 2016 Cyber Security Summit the launch of the "Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative," further enhancing the Hong Kong banking sector's capacity to withstand cyber attacks.

# June

# 1–2 June

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission co-hosted a senior seminar for independent non-executive directors of Hong Kong's banking sector.

# 3 June

The 2016 Inland Revenue (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance came into force, allowing companies to deduct interest expenses from group internal financing operations under specified conditions, and providing tax incentives for Hong Kong's corporate treasury centres.

# 10 June

The 2016 Securities and Futures (Amendment) Ordinance was gazetted, introducing a new structure for open-ended fund companies and making Hong Kong's fund registration platform more diversified.

# June 20

Under the Government bond programme, the issuance of the sixth batch of retail inflation-linked bonds (iBond).

# June 30

The Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance was proclaimed, providing a legal basis for establishing a cross-sector financial institutions resolution mechanism in Hong Kong.

# July

# July 4th

The HKMA signed Memorandums of Understanding with the International Finance Corporation and the Global Infrastructure Centre through the IFFO platform to promote investment and financing in Asian infrastructure projects.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) to promote Hong Kong's development into an infrastructure financing hub.

# July 5th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Boao Forum for Asia co-hosted a financial cooperation meeting themed "Financial Promotion of the Real Economy" in Hong Kong.

# July 20

The electronic cheque joint settlement between Guangdong Province (including Shenzhen) and Hong Kong has been initiated.

# August

# August 12

Issue the first batch of Silver bonds under the government bond programme.

# 25 August

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced that it has granted the first batch of stored value payment tools licences to five issuers of stored value payment tools under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Payment Tools Ordinance (Payment Ordinance).

# September

# September 6th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will co-host the "2016 Treasury Market Summit" in Hong Kong with the Treasury Market Association.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has launched the "Fintech Regulatory Sandbox", allowing banks to pilot test financial technology and other technology projects before their full launch.

# September 28

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority presided over a seminar hosted in Frankfurt, Germany, promoting Hong Kong's role in China's opportunities.

# October

# October 24 to 25

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the Bank of England, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will jointly host a high-level seminar titled "Interactions between Monetary, Financial, and Prudential Regulatory Policies after the Financial Crisis" in Hong Kong.

# October 26th to 28th

IFFO hosted the first administrative personnel workshop titled "Private Participation in Investment and Financing of Emerging Market Infrastructure Projects" and announced that 13 more institutions have joined as IFFO partners, bringing the total to over 50.

# 27 October

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has expanded its RMB Primary Liquidity Provider (PLP) Programme, increasing the number of participating banks from seven to nine and raising the total amount of the programme to RMB18 billion. The transparency of the usage of the RMB liquidity funding arrangements has also increased.

# November

# November 4

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced that it has granted the second batch of licences for stored value payment facilities, bringing the total number of licensees for such facilities to 13.

# 經濟及金融環境

隨着環球經濟及貿易活動疲弱，香港經濟增長在2016年回軟。面對外圍環境不明朗因素加劇，預期2017年經濟增長仍然溫和。

# 經濟回顧

# 概覽

香港經濟增長在2016年放緩，實質本地生產總值增長由2015年的2.4%降至1.9%（表1）。淨出口是主要拖累，當中訪港旅遊業疲弱令服務輸出受壓（圖1）。本地需求動力亦放緩，但繼續為整體經濟增長提供主要支持。勞工市場大致保持穩定，失業率維持於3.3至3.4%的低位。由於本地成本及外部價格壓力減退，消費物價通脹進一步放緩。面對波動的外圍環境及多變的市場氣氛，資產市場增添起伏。鑑於住宅物業市場再度暢旺，政府於11月實施新印花稅措施。

儘管外圍環境波動及美元利率上升，本港外匯及貨幣市場繼續運作暢順。港元現貨匯率於1月份略為轉弱後一直在7.75附近水平徘徊。年內兌換保證並無被觸發，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券合計幾乎維持不變，約為1.2萬億港元。繼美國於12月中加息後，金管局基本利率由0.75厘上調至1厘。香港銀行同業拆息及較長期債券收益率維持在相對較低水平，但在接近年底時稍升，部分反映美元相應拆息及收益率的走勢。整體銀行貸款增長在2016年加快至6.5%。雖然整體貸款質素略為轉差，但特定分類貸款比率仍然維持在極低水平。

圖 1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻
資料來源：政府統計處。

表 1 按開支項目計的實質本地生產總值增長（比對上期）

註：本地固定資本形成總額經季節因素調整的按季增減幅度不詳。
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 本地需求

本地需求的增長力度在2016年略為減弱。儘管穩定的就業及收入狀況繼續為私人消費帶來支持，但其增速仍降至1.6%，部分反映經濟不明朗因素加劇。政府消費增長亦略為減慢至3.3%。本地固定資本形成總額繼續按季大幅上落（圖2），累計全年收縮0.5%。私營部門機器及設備購置成為主要拖累，在營商前景欠佳下連續第3年收縮，而樓宇及建造活動則因住屋動工項目增加而轉殷。

圖 2 本地需求
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 外部需求

香港出口在接近2016年底時有回穩跡象，但綜合全年表現仍然乏力（圖3）。貨品出口較2015年的低基數上升1.7%。香港對先進經濟體的出口仍然呆滯；但在區內貿易流動轉趨穩定下，香港對中國內地、印度、韓國、新加坡及台灣的出口則較2015年好轉。

部分反映零售銷售在近年急速增長後轉趨正常化，香港服務輸出在2016年顯著收縮3.1%。貨品進口在2015年收縮後於2016年收復部分失地，服務輸入則部分受惠於本地居民外遊意欲而持續增長。2016年整體貿易順差收窄，拖累本地經濟增長。

圖 3 貨品出口及服務輸出
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 通脹

通脹壓力在2016年仍然受控。剔除政府一次性紓緩措施的影響後，基本通脹率由2015年的2.5%下降至2016年的2.3%（圖4）。在早前新訂私人住宅租金下調所帶來的傳遞效應下，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹回落。受惠於全球商品價格偏軟及港元強勢，進口價格通脹受到遏抑。另一方面，在勞工成本穩定增長及租金成本壓力（尤其零售範疇）有所紓緩下，本地成本壓力保持溫和。

圖 4 基本消費物價通脹
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 勞工市場

勞工市場在2016年大致保持穩定，勞工供求升幅相若。按行業分析，旅遊相關行業的勞工市場狀況轉差，其他行業則大致平穩。整體而言，經季節因素調整失業率由2015年的3.3%稍升至3.4%（圖5）。在勞工市場穩定下，名義工資在首3季上升3.8%，而2015年的升幅為4.6%。首3季實質工資亦上升0.9%，而2015年的升幅為1.5%。

圖 5 勞工市場狀況
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 股市

香港股市在2016年大幅上落。受到人民幣貶值壓力及內地股市波動所影響，恒生指數於2月份跌至3年來的低位（圖6）。本港股市在3月份跟隨美國及其他主要股市顯著造好而回升。儘管英國脫歐公投觸發市場波動，但在外界預期美國聯邦儲備局會放緩加息步伐及其他主要央行推行貨幣寬鬆政策下，市場氣氛迅速改善。恒生指數於9月份升至24,100點的一年高位。然而，受到美國總統選舉結果及預計美國會加快加息步伐所影響，本港股市在第4季再度受壓。整體而言，恒生指數於2016年微升0.4%，在2015年則下跌7.2%。平均每日成交額由上年的1,056億港元降至669億港元，而本港股市集資總額亦由上年的11,156億港元減少至4,901億港元。

圖 6 資產價格
資料來源：差餉物業估價署及香港交易及結算所有限公司。

# 物業市場

住宅物業市場在2016年略為波動。物業成交量於第1季錄得歷史新低後，在其後數月有所回升，但在11月推出新印花稅措施後再度下挫。整體而言，成交量在2016年稍跌至54,701宗。另一方面，樓價自第2季起上升並超越2015年9月的高位，2016年的累計升幅為7.8%（圖6）。置業負擔能力依然偏緊，樓價與收入比率為15.9，超越1997年的歷史高位；而收入槓桿比率為72.0%，遠高於長期平均水平。2 由於銀行推出具競爭力的按揭計劃，按揭利率稍為回落，於接近年底時則跟隨香港銀行同業拆息上升而略為回升。工商物業市場方面，全年交投大致保持穩定。由於非住宅物業價格較2015年高位回落，相應租金收益率較上年微升，但仍處於低位。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

預期2017年實質本地生產總值增長將保持溫和。政府預測經濟增長幅度介乎2至3%之間，私營機構分析員預測增幅平均為2.0%。外圍方面，隨着環球宏觀經濟及金融環境變得不明朗，全球經濟及貿易增長或會保持溫和；再加上港元實質有效匯率因美元強勢而上升，將會抑制香港的出口表現。本地方面，雖然穩定的就業及收入狀況會支持消費，但受利率上升所拖累，預期私人消費會溫和增長。受惠於住屋供應增加及多個基建項目展開，樓宇及建造活動應會穩步增長，但營商氣氛疲弱及利率趨升將影響商界資本投資。

# 通脹及勞工市場

預計2017年通脹壓力仍然溫和。一方面環球商品價格上漲及中國內地通脹趨升或會令進口價格上升，另一方面港元轉強卻可能會令上述壓力受到遏抑。在溫和的經濟動力下，本地成本壓力仍可受控，但由於新訂住宅租金於2017年初上升，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹可能會稍升。市場共識預測2017年整體通脹率為1.9%，政府預期基本通脹率為2.0%。雖然不明朗因素加劇或會影響招聘意欲，私營機構分析員預計2017年失業率會維持於3.4%。

# 不明朗因素及風險

2017年經濟前景會受制於眾多不明朗因素，當中來自外圍環境的影響尤甚。美國新一屆政府政策的不確定性，將令環球經濟前景變得不明朗，當中可能出現的保護主義政策亦會對全球貿易帶來阻力。英國脫歐進程及歐洲幾個主要國家舉行大選，亦可能導致資產市場波動，並影響港元資金流向。此外，美國利率正常化將會令本地貨幣狀況收緊，並對實質經濟及資產價格構成下調壓力；當中樓市繼續偏緊，市場前景仍然很不明朗。短期而言，按揭息率仍然偏低、就業及收入狀況穩定，以及地產發展商加推優惠（例如折扣及現金回贈）令累積的購買力獲得釋放，均可為住宅需求帶來支持。另一方面，新印花稅措施、美國可能加快加息步伐及房屋供應穩步增長，則可能繼續為樓市帶來阻力。

# 銀行體系表現

儘管本港經濟面對阻力，加上國際政治事件出乎意料的結果令市場波動加劇，香港銀行體系在2016年仍然穩健。認可機構的資本及流動性狀況維持良好，資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處於健康水平。

# 利率走勢

隨着美國利率上升，香港銀行同業拆息在11月及12月顯著上升。反映零售銀行港元資金成本的綜合利率則輕微上升（圖7）。

圖 7 香港銀行同業拆息、綜合利率及最優惠貸款利率

註：
1. 香港銀行同業拆息（每月平均數）由香港銀行公會公布。
2. 最優惠貸款利率（每月平均數）是參考香港上海滙豐銀行有限公司所報利率。

# 盈利走勢

零售銀行在2016年的盈利略為改善，其香港業務的整體除稅前經營溢利增長8.7%。增長主要是由外匯及衍生工具業務收入（+39.7%）、附屬公司派發的股息收入（+123.5%）及淨利息收入（+2.8%）所帶動，不過部份增長被費用及佣金收入減少(-11.3%)所抵銷。零售銀行除稅後溢利錄得44.4%的升幅，增長主要來自非經常項目。零售銀行除稅後平均資產回報率亦相應由2015 年的 1.04% 上升至 1.44%（圖 8）。

圖8 零售銀行的表現

2016年零售銀行淨息差為1.32%，與2015年的水平相同（圖9）。雖然零售銀行繼續將剩餘資金配置於息率較低而流動性較高的金融投資，但利息收益的減少被利息成本下降所抵銷。

圖9 零售銀行淨息差

零售銀行非利息收入佔總經營收入的比例為44.3%，大致維持穩定。雖然費用與佣金收入下跌11.3%，但股息收入及外匯與衍生工具業務收入分別上升123.5%及39.7%。

# economic and financial environment

With global economic and trade activities subdued, Hong Kong's economic growth softened in 2016. Faced with intensified uncertainties in the external environment, economic growth is expected to remain moderate in 2017.

# Economic Review

# Overview

Hong Kong's economic growth slowed in 2016, with real local GDP growth declining from 2.4% in 2015 to 1.9% (Table 1). Net exports were the main drag, with weakness in the tourism sector weighing down services exports (Figure 1). Local demand momentum also slowed, but continued to provide the main support for overall economic growth. The labor market remained largely stable, with the unemployment rate maintained at a low level of 3.3 to 3.4%. Due to the easing of local cost pressures and external price pressures, consumer price inflation further slowed. Faced with a volatile external environment and changing market sentiment, asset markets added volatility. In light of the revival of the residential property market, the government implemented new stamp duty measures in November.

Despite the volatility in the external environment and the rise in US dollar interest rates, Hong Kong's foreign exchange and currency markets continue to operate smoothly. The Hong Kong dollar spot exchange rate, after slightly weakening in January, has continued to hover around the 7.75 level. The exchange guarantee was not triggered during the year, and the total surplus combined with outstanding foreign exchange fund bills and bonds remained almost unchanged, amounting to approximately 1.2 trillion Hong Kong dollars. Following the US interest rate hike in mid-December, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority raised its basic interest rate from 0.75% to 1%. Hong Kong interbank offered rates (HIBOR) and longer-term bond yields remained at relatively low levels, but slightly increased as the year approached its end, partly reflecting the trends in corresponding US dollar interbank rates and yields. Overall bank loan growth accelerated to 6.5% in 2016. Although overall loan quality slightly deteriorated, the specific classified loan ratios remained at extremely low levels.

Figure 1: Contribution of Components to Real Local GDP Growth. Source: Census and Statistics Department.

Table 1: Real Domestic GDP Growth by Expenditure Items (Compared to the Previous Period)

Note: The quarterly changes in the adjusted total amount of local fixed capital formation are not available.  
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

#LocalDemand

The growth momentum of local demand slightly weakened in 2016. Despite stable employment and income conditions continuing to support private consumption, its growth rate still fell to 1.6%, partly reflecting intensified economic uncertainties. Government consumption growth also slightly slowed to 3.3%. The total fixed capital formation in the local economy continued to fluctuate markedly on a quarterly basis (Chart 2), with a cumulative annual contraction of 0.5%. Machinery and equipment purchases by the private sector became the main drag, contracting for the third consecutive year under a poor business outlook, while building and construction activities turned more positive due to an increase in housing construction projects.

Figure 2 Local Demand Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# External Demand

Hong Kong exports showed signs of stabilizing near the end of 2016, but the performance for the whole year remained weak (Figure 3). Goods exports rose 1.7% compared to the low base of 2015. Hong Kong's exports to advanced economies remained sluggish; however, under more stable regional trade flows, exports to mainland China, India, South Korea, Singapore, and Taiwan improved compared to 2015.

Partly reflecting the normalization of retail sales after a period of rapid growth in recent years, Hong Kong's exports of services contracted significantly by 3.1% in 2016. Goods imports, which had contracted in 2015, regained some ground in 2016, while imports of services continued to grow, partially benefiting from the desire of local residents to travel abroad. The overall trade surplus narrowed in 2016, dragging down local economic growth.

Figure 3 Exports of Goods and Exports of Services  
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Inflation

Inflation pressures remained controlled in 2016. After excluding the impact of the government's one-time relief measures, the core inflation rate fell from 2.5% in 2015 to 2.3% in 2016 (Chart 4). Under the translation effect from earlier newly introduced private residential rent reductions, the inflation component of rent in the Composite Consumer Price Index declined. Benefiting from softer global commodity prices and a strong Hong Kong dollar, import price inflation was curbed. On the other hand, local cost pressures remained moderate, as the stable growth in labor costs and rent cost pressures (particularly in the retail sector) eased.

Figure 4 Basic Consumer Price Inflation Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# labour market

The labour market remained largely stable in 2016, with similar increases in labour supply and demand. By industry analysis, the labour market conditions in tourism-related industries deteriorated, while other industries remained largely stable. Overall, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose slightly from 3.3% in 2015 to 3.4% (Chart 5). Under the stable labour market, labour earnings in nominal terms increased by 3.8% in the first three quarters, compared to an increase of 4.6% in 2015. Real wages also increased by 0.9% in the first three quarters, compared to an increase of 1.5% in 2015.

Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Stock Market

The Hong Kong stock market experienced significant fluctuations in 2016. Affected by the pressure from the depreciation of the renminbi and the volatility in the mainland stock market, the Hang Seng Index fell to a three-year low in February (Figure 6). The Hong Kong stock market rebounded in March, following the significant recovery in the US and other major stock markets. Despite the UK's Brexit referendum triggering market volatility, market sentiment quickly improved under external expectations that the US Federal Reserve would slow its rate hikes and other major central banks implementing monetary easing policies. The Hang Seng Index rose to a one-year high of 24,100 points in September. However, the Hong Kong stock market faced renewed pressure in the fourth quarter, influenced by the outcome of the US presidential election and expectations that the US would accelerate its rate hikes. Overall, the Hang Seng Index rose slightly by 0.4% in 2016, compared to a 7.2% decline in 2015. The average daily turnover fell from 105.6 billion Hong Kong dollars in the previous year to 66.9 billion Hong Kong dollars, while the total fundraising amount in the Hong Kong stock market also decreased from 1,115.6 billion Hong Kong dollars in the previous year to 490.1 billion Hong Kong dollars.

Figure 6: Asset Prices  
Source: Rates and Valuation Department and Hong Kong Trading and Settlement Limited.

# Property Market

The residential property market experienced slight volatility in 2016. After recording a historical low in the first quarter, property turnover recovered somewhat in the subsequent months, but fell again following the introduction of new stamp duty measures in November. Overall, turnover in 2016 slightly declined to 54,701 transactions. On the other hand, property prices rose since the second quarter and surpassed the peak recorded in September 2015, with a cumulative increase of 7.8% in 2016 (Chart 6). Housing affordability remains tight, with the price-to-income ratio at 15.9, exceeding the historical high in 1997; the income leverage ratio was 72.0%, far above the long-term average. 2 Due to banks introducing competitive mortgage schemes, mortgage rates slightly declined, but slightly recovered as they approached the end of the year, following the rise in Hong Kong interbank offered rates. In the commercial property market, year-round trading volume remained largely stable. Due to non-residential property prices falling from the 2015 peak, corresponding rental yields slightly increased compared to the previous year, but remained at a low level.

# Economic Prospects

# Economic Environment

The real local GDP growth is expected to remain moderate in 2017. The government forecasts economic growth to range between 2% and 3%, while private sector analysts predict an average increase of 2.0%. Externally, as the global macroeconomic and financial environment becomes more uncertain, global economic and trade growth is likely to remain moderate. Additionally, the rise in the Hong Kong dollar's real effective exchange rate, driven by the strength of the US dollar, is expected to dampen Hong Kong's export performance. Locally, although stable employment and income conditions are expected to support consumption, private consumption is anticipated to grow only moderately due to the drag from rising interest rates. Benefiting from increased housing supply and the commencement of several infrastructure projects, building and construction activities should grow steadily. However, a weak business climate and rising interest rates are likely to affect business capital investment.

# Inflation and Labour Market

Inflationary pressure is expected to remain moderate in 2017. On one hand, rising global commodity prices and increasing inflation in China could lead to higher import prices, while on the other hand, a stronger HK dollar may suppress these pressures. Under moderate economic momentum, local cost pressures are expected to remain controlled, but due to the rise in new residential rental prices in early 2017, inflation in the rent component of the Composite Consumer Price Index may rise slightly. The market consensus forecasts an overall inflation rate of 1.9% for 2017, while the government expects the core inflation rate to be 2.0%. Although increased uncertainty may affect hiring intentions, private sector analysts expect the unemployment rate to remain at 3.4% in 2017.

# Uncertainty Factors and Risks

The economic outlook for 2017 will be constrained by numerous uncertainties, with the impact from the external environment being particularly significant. The uncertainty surrounding the policies of the new US government will make the global economic outlook more uncertain, and potential protectionist policies may also pose resistance to global trade. The Brexit process and the upcoming elections in several major European countries may also lead to asset market volatility and affect the flow of Hong Kong dollar funds. Additionally, the normalization of US interest rates will tighten local monetary conditions and exert downward pressure on the real economy and asset prices; the property market remains particularly tight, and market prospects remain highly uncertain. In the short term, low mortgage rates, stable employment and income conditions, and the introduction of additional incentives by property developers (such as discounts and cash rebates) have released accumulated purchasing power, providing support for residential demand. On the other hand, new stamp duty measures, the potential acceleration of US interest rate hikes, and the steady growth in housing supply may continue to pose resistance to the property market.

# Banking system performance

Despite Hong Kong's economy facing resistance, coupled with unexpected outcomes from international political events intensifying market volatility, the Hong Kong banking system remained sound in 2016. Authorised institutions maintained good capital and liquidity conditions, with asset quality showing slight deterioration, but still remained at healthy levels.

# Interest Rate Trends

With the rise in US interest rates, Hong Kong banks' interbank interest rates rose significantly in November and December. The composite interest rate reflecting retail banks' Hong Kong dollar funding costs increased slightly (Figure 7).

# Profit Trend

Retail banking's profits slightly improved in 2016, with its Hong Kong business's overall pre-tax operating profit growing by 8.7%. The growth was mainly driven by foreign exchange and derivatives business income (+39.7%), dividend income from subsidiary companies (+123.5%), and net interest income (+2.8%), although part of the growth was offset by a decrease in expenses and commission income (-11.3%). Retail banking's post-tax profit recorded a 44.4% increase, with the growth primarily coming from non-recurring items. Retail banking's post-tax average return on assets also rose correspondingly from 1.04% in 2015 to 1.44% (Chart 8).

Chart 8: Performance of Retail Banking

In 2016, the net interest margin of retail banks was 1.32%, the same as the level in 2015 (Chart 9). Although retail banks continued to allocate their remaining funds to financial investments with lower interest rates but higher liquidity, the decrease in interest income was offset by the decline in interest costs.

Chart 9 Retail Bank Net Interest Difference

Retail banks' non-interest income accounted for 44.3% of total operating income, remaining largely stable. Although fee and commission income fell by 11.3%, dividend income and foreign exchange and derivatives business income rose by 123.5% and 39.7% respectively.

# 貨幣穩定

儘管外圍環境波動及美元息率上升，港元匯率在2016年仍然保持穩定。香港貨幣市場亦繼續運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。聯繫匯率制度繼續展現高度承受衝擊的能力，是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：
- 負債證明書（為3間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣
- 銀行在金管局所持結算戶口的結餘總額（即總結餘）
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。若市場對港元的需求大過供應，令市場匯率轉強至7.75港元兌1美元的強方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行沽出港元、買入美元，使總結餘增加及港元利率下跌，從而令港元匯率從強方兌換保證匯率水平回復至7.75到7.85的兌換範圍內。相反，若港元供過於求，令市場匯率轉弱至7.85港元兌1美元的弱方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行買入港元，使總結餘減少及推高港元利率，港元匯率隨之由弱方兌換保證匯率水平回復至兌換範圍內。

# 2016年回顧

# 匯率穩定

港元匯率在2016年首兩個月略有波動後，於年內餘下時間一直窄幅徘徊。港元在2016年初兌美元顯著轉弱，由1月4日的7.7510降至1月20日的7.8196（圖1）。港元匯率轉弱符合聯繫匯率制度的正常運作，反映美國在2015年12月加息後港元與美元的負息差擴濶。此外，其他市場相關因素，包括香港股市出現拋售、內地及香港經濟前景不及以前樂觀、人民幣匯率波動增加，以及亞洲貨幣普遍疲弱，均導致港元需求減弱。受到市場氣氛改善支持，港元匯率在2月略為轉強，並自3月起一直在7.753至7.776之間窄幅徘徊，即使英國脫歐公投及美國總統選舉引發市場波動亦未受影響。由於市場預期美國會在夏季加息，港元匯率於5月出現短暫的轉弱壓力。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2016年一直正常運作。

圖 1 2016年市場匯率

由於兌換保證沒有被觸發，因此總結餘及未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額在2016年沒有明顯變動，大致維持在12,222億港元左右（圖2）。年內金管局增發總值1,320億港元的外匯基金票據，以滿足銀行在流動性管理方面的龐大需求，令總結餘相應減少至2016年底的2,596億港元。增發外匯基金票據符合貨幣發行局制度的原則，這是由於增發外匯基金票據只屬貨幣基礎組成部分之間的轉移，即由總結餘移至未償還外匯基金票據及債券，貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

圖 2 2016年總結餘及未償還外匯基金票據及債券

# 貨幣市場

香港銀行同業拆息在2016年大部分時間維持在較低水平（圖3）。香港銀行同業拆息在1、2月期間因金融市場波動加劇而面對一些上升壓力，但在3月隨着金融環境回復平靜而轉趨穩定。於第2及第3季，儘管市場關注英國脫歐公投結果以及美國貨幣市場基金改革，香港銀行同業拆息仍大致保持穩定。部分受到年底資金需求影響，以及港元拆息追回美元拆息的升幅，香港銀行同業拆息在第4季錄得較大升幅。儘管如此，短期銀行同業拆息在2016年大致維持在低於基本利率的水平。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍於12月14日（美國時間）由0.25至0.50厘上調至0.50至0.75厘，基本利率於12月15日由0.75厘上調至1.00厘。基本利率的調整是按照於2009年3月26日宣布的經修訂計算公式作出。按照該公式，基本利率定於美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍下限加50基點的水平，或隔夜與1個月香港銀行同業拆息的5天移動平均數的平均值水平，兩者以較高者為準。

港元遠期匯率點子在1月出現大幅溢價，大致跟隨港元與美元息差的走勢，以及部分反映投資者為其港股組合作出外匯對沖的需求（圖4）。遠期匯率溢價在2月開始收窄。隨着市況轉趨穩定，港元遠期匯率點子在3至11月期間大致保持穩定，其後在12月因港元與美元息差收窄而再度上升。整體而言，香港貨幣市場運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。貼現窗借貸在2016年並不活躍，僅涉及53億港元。

# 聯繫匯率制度

儘管經歷多次區內以至全球金融危機，聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）過去數十年來一直是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。2016年初市場波動加劇，再度引起有關港元轉弱及情況有如亞洲金融危機時期的評論。為增進各界對聯匯制度的認識，金管局向公眾闡釋聯匯制度的技術細節，並指出香港金融體系有能力抵禦衝擊。政府亦重申堅決維持聯匯制度。外匯及貨幣市場穩定，進一步鞏固公眾對政府維持聯匯制度的決心以及港元作為支付及保值貨幣的信心。國際貨幣基金組織在與香港進行年度第四條磋商時，明確表示聯匯制度是最適合香港的貨幣制度，指出香港靈活的經濟結構、充裕的財政及儲備緩衝、以及穩健有效的金融監管是聯匯制度的後盾。

圖 4 2016年美元兌港元遠期匯率點子

鑑於穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用，金管局繼續密切監察銀行的信用、流動性及利率風險管理以及壓力測試結果，並加強對銀行個人、企業及內地相關貸款的監管，以確保銀行體系具備應付衝擊的能力。面對美國貨幣政策正常化，香港銀行同業拆息開始上升，金管局提醒市民保持警覺，並作好準備以應付可能出現的市場波動及風險。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）於2016年在106.3至107.5%之間的窄幅上落，並無觸及上限或下限。該比率於2016年12月31日為106.7%（圖5）。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，能在面對突如其來的衝擊時為香港貨幣及金融穩定提供強力後盾。

# 研究工作

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的貨幣發行委員會負責監察和探討與香港貨幣及金融穩定有關的課題。在2016年，貨幣發行委員會探討的課題包括香港與中國內地及美國經濟增長同步性、港元貨幣外部需求及香港的金融狀況指數。貨幣發行委員會會議紀錄及金管局向其呈交的貨幣發行局制度運作報告，均載於金管局網站。

香港金融研究中心繼續支持貨幣政策、銀行業及金融範疇的研究工作。在2016年，研究中心合共邀請18位學者到訪，並發表20份工作論文。

# 紙幣及硬幣

截至2016年底，流通銀行紙幣（指發鈔銀行發行的紙幣）總值4,078億港元，較上年增加13.2%（圖6、7及8）。政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣總值118億港元，較上年增加5.3%（圖9及10）。在政府發行的紙幣及硬幣中，10港元流通紙幣總值44億港元，當中塑質鈔票佔86%。

# Currency Stability

Despite the volatility in the external environment and rising US dollar interest rates, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate maintained stability in 2016. Hong Kong's monetary market also continued to operate smoothly, with ample liquidity in the interbank sector. The linked exchange rate system continued to demonstrate a high capacity to withstand shocks, serving as the cornerstone of Hong Kong's monetary and financial stability.

# target

The primary objective of Hong Kong's monetary policy is to maintain currency stability, i.e., to ensure the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, keeping the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar against the US dollar within a range of 7.75 to 7.85 Hong Kong dollars per 1 US dollar in the foreign exchange market. This monetary system mainly adopts the monetary issuance system, stipulating that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund provide at least 100% support to the monetary base; if the monetary base changes, the US dollar reserves must also make corresponding adjustments, fully aligning with the changes in the monetary base.

Monetary Base (Table 1) includes:  
- Liability certificates (providing full support for banknotes issued by three issuing banks)  
- Government-issued circulating banknotes and coins  
- The total balance of settlement accounts held by banks at the HKMA (i.e., total balance)  
- Foreign exchange fund bills and notes issued by the HKMA on behalf of the government.

Table 1: Monetary Base

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through its automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and its firm commitment to fulfilling the exchange guarantee. If market demand for Hong Kong dollars exceeds supply, causing the market exchange rate to strengthen to the strong-side exchange guarantee rate of 7.75 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will sell Hong Kong dollars and buy US dollars from banks, increasing total reserves and causing the Hong Kong dollar interest rate to fall, thereby returning the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate to the exchange rate range of 7.75 to 7.85. Conversely, if Hong Kong dollars are in excess supply, causing the market exchange rate to weaken to the weak-side exchange guarantee rate of 7.85 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will buy Hong Kong dollars from banks, reducing total reserves and raising the Hong Kong dollar interest rate, thereby returning the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate to the exchange rate range.

# 2016 Review

# Exchange Rate Stability

The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained within a narrow range for the rest of 2016 after experiencing slight fluctuations in the first two months of the year. Early in 2016, the Hong Kong dollar significantly weakened against the US dollar, falling from 7.7510 on January 4 to 7.8196 on January 20 (Figure 1). This weakening of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate aligned with the normal operation of the linked exchange rate system, reflecting the widening negative interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar following the US Federal Reserve's December 2015 interest rate hike. Additionally, other market-related factors, including the sell-off in the Hong Kong stock market, declining optimism regarding the economic outlooks of both mainland China and Hong Kong, increased volatility in the Renminbi exchange rate, and the general weakness of Asian currencies, all contributed to a decline in demand for the Hong Kong dollar. Supported by improved market sentiment, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate slightly strengthened in February and remained within a narrow range between 7.753 and 7.776 from March onward, remaining unaffected even by market volatility triggered by the Brexit referendum and the US presidential election. Overall, the Hong Kong foreign exchange market operated normally throughout 2016.

Chart 1 2016 Market Exchange Rate

As the convertibility guarantee was not triggered, the total surplus and the aggregate outstanding amount of foreign exchange fund bills and notes remained largely unchanged in 2016, staying around 122.22 billion Hong Kong dollars (Chart 2). During the year, the HKMA issued additional foreign exchange fund bills and notes totaling 13.2 billion Hong Kong dollars to meet the substantial liquidity management demands of banks, causing the total surplus to correspondingly decline to 25.96 billion Hong Kong dollars by the end of 2016. The issuance of additional foreign exchange fund bills and notes conforms to the principles of the currency board system, as such issuance merely represents a transfer within components of the monetary base—from the total surplus to the outstanding foreign exchange fund bills and notes—while the monetary base continues to be fully backed by foreign exchange reserves.

Figure 2 2016 Aggregate Balance and Outstanding Foreign Exchange Fund Bills & Notes

# Money Market

HIBOR remained at relatively low levels for most of 2016 (Chart 3). During January and February, HIBOR faced some upward pressure due to increased volatility in financial markets, but turned more stable in March as the financial environment calmed down. In the second and third quarters, despite market concerns over the outcome of the UK Brexit referendum and US money market fund reforms, HIBOR remained largely stable. Partly due to year-end funding demands and HIBOR catching up with the rise in US dollar rates, HIBOR recorded a significant increase in the fourth quarter. Despite this, short-term interbank rates remained below the base rate level throughout 2016.

In response to the US Federal Funds Rate target range being raised from 0.25 to 0.50厘 to 0.50 to 0.75厘 on December 14 (US time), the basic interest rate was raised from 0.75厘 to 1.00厘 on December 15. The adjustment of the basic interest rate was made in accordance with the revised calculation formula announced on March 26, 2009. According to this formula, the basic interest rate is set at the level of the lower bound of the US Federal Funds Rate target range plus 50 basis points, or the average level of the 5-day moving average of the overnight and 1-month Hong Kong interbank interest rates, whichever is higher.

Chart 3 2016 Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rates

The Hong Kong dollar forward exchange rate points experienced a marked premium in January, largely following the trends of the interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar, as well as partly reflecting investors' demand for foreign exchange hedging for their Hong Kong stock portfolios (Figure 4). The forward exchange rate premium began to narrow in February. As market conditions turned more stable, Hong Kong dollar forward exchange rate points remained largely stable during the period from March to November, and then rose again in December due to the narrowing of the interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar. Overall, the Hong Kong money market operated smoothly, with ample interbank liquidity. Discount window lending was not active in 2016, involving only HK$5.3 billion.

# Linked Exchange Rate System

Despite experiencing multiple regional and global financial crises, the linked exchange rate system (Linked Exchange Rate System) has been the cornerstone of Hong Kong's monetary and financial stability over the past several decades. In early 2016, intensified market volatility once again sparked comments about the weakening of the Hong Kong dollar and a situation similar to the Asian financial crisis period. To enhance understanding of the Linked Exchange Rate System among various sectors, the HKMA explained the technical details of the system to the public and pointed out that Hong Kong's financial system has the capacity to withstand shocks. The government also reaffirmed its firm commitment to maintaining the Linked Exchange Rate System. Stability in foreign exchange and currency markets further solidified public confidence in the government's resolve to maintain the Linked Exchange Rate System and in the Hong Kong dollar as a currency for payment and preservation of value. During its annual Article IV consultation with Hong Kong, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) clearly stated that the Linked Exchange Rate System is the most suitable monetary system for Hong Kong, noting that Hong Kong's flexible economic structure, ample fiscal and reserve buffers, and sound and effective financial regulation serve as the backing for the Linked Exchange Rate System.

Chart 4 2016 US$ against HK$ Forward Exchange Rate Points

In the light of the critical role of a sound banking system in the normal operation of the linked exchange rate system, the HKMA continues to closely monitor banks' credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as the results of stress tests, and strengthens oversight of banks' personal, corporate, and mainland-related lending to ensure the banking system has the capacity to address shocks. Facing the normalization of US monetary policy, Hong Kong's interbank interest rates have begun to rise. The HKMA reminds the public to stay vigilant and be well-prepared to cope with potential market volatility and risks.

To enhance the transparency of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's accounts, since October 1998, part of the Exchange Fund's assets have been designated to support the currency base. The support ratio (i.e., the ratio of supporting assets relative to the currency base) fluctuated within a narrow range between 106.3% and 107.5% in 2016, without reaching the upper or lower limits. The ratio was 106.7% on December 31, 2016 (Chart 5). Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, although certain Exchange Fund assets have been designated as part of the support portfolio, all of the Exchange Fund's assets can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The Exchange Fund's substantial fiscal resources can provide strong support for Hong Kong's monetary and financial stability in the face of sudden shocks.

# Research Work

The Currency Board, under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, is responsible for monitoring and examining subjects related to Hong Kong's monetary and financial stability. In 2016, the topics discussed by the Currency Board included the synchronization of Hong Kong's economic growth with that of mainland China and the US, external demand for Hong Kong dollars, and Hong Kong's financial conditions index. The minutes of the Currency Board meetings and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's reports on the operation of the Currency Board system are both available on the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's website.

The Hong Kong Financial Research Centre continues to support research in monetary policy, the banking sector, and the financial sector. In 2016, the research centre invited a total of 18 scholars to visit and published 20 working papers.

Within the year, the Research Centre organised six international conferences and seminars, mainly including:
- In January, hosted the 7th Annual International Conference on the Chinese Economy, with the theme "China's growing influence on the global economy." During the conference, eight research papers covering a wide range of topics were presented, including China's growth rebalancing and growth potential, economic spillover effects from China, the impact of the RMB on the global and regional economies, and the trends in interest rate differentials and information flows between RMB markets.
- In March, co-hosted with the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology and Keio University the "HKUST, Keio University, and Research Centre Conference on Exchange Rates and Macroeconomics." The content covered multiple economic issues, including global economic imbalances, exchange rate dynamics, capital controls, and monetary policy.
- In August, co-hosted with Hong Kong City University the "Real Estate and Financial Stability Seminar." Papers presented at the seminar covered topics such as age, demographics, and housing demand; the impact of large investors on asset quality; dynamics of Hong Kong housing prices; housing market affordability; the impact of mortgage regulations on housing decisions across the family life cycle; and the residential property market in mainland China.
- In October, co-hosted with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Bank for International Settlements a conference on the Asia-Pacific economic system, with the theme "The resilience of the regional economic system in the face of a turbulent global environment." The conference attracted senior officials from multiple central banks, leading scholars, and experts from international organizations and private institutions, who engaged in interactive roundtable discussions to exchange views on the most pressing issues facing the Asia-Pacific economic system. The topics discussed were broad, including financial imbalances in Asia, capital flows, the spillover effects of the slowdown in mainland China's economy on other regions, and the impact on and prospects for Asia's potential growth.

The Centre also hosted the "14th Annual Summer Seminar" in August and the "14th China Mainland Economic Seminar" in September, discussing asset quality and financial stability matters of Mainland China's banking sector. The aforementioned meetings and seminars attracted participants from academia, the financial services sector, and representatives from central banks around the world. The Centre also hosted 21 open small seminars within the year, discussing a wide range of economic, monetary, and financial issues.

# Banknotes and Coins

As of the end of 2016, the total value of circulating banknotes (referring to banknotes issued by issuing banks) amounted to 407.8 billion Hong Kong dollars, an increase of 13.2% compared to the previous year (Charts 6, 7, and 8). The total value of circulating banknotes and coins issued by the Government was 11.8 billion Hong Kong dollars, an increase of 5.3% compared to the previous year (Charts 9 and 10). Among the banknotes and coins issued by the Government, the total value of circulating 10 Hong Kong dollar banknotes was 4.4 billion Hong Kong dollars, of which polymer banknotes accounted for 86%.

# 銀行體系穩定

儘管環球市場風險及震盪增加，香港銀行體系在2016年仍維持穩健。金管局在年內加強監管認可機構的風險管治架構，以及信用與流動性風險管理系統的成效。鑑於網絡攻擊日趨頻繁，金管局亦加強監管認可機構的科技風險管理。為貫徹金管局致力打擊金融罪行的目標，認可機構打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集監控措施的成效，繼續是金管局的監管重點。在監管認可機構的操守方面，金管局採取實質行動，推動以客為本的企業文化及促進普及金融，和應對海外中小企及初創企業在香港開立及維持銀行帳戶方面遇到的困難。金管局亦加強監管認可機構銷售投資及保險產品的手法，以進一步提升對客戶的保障。

# 監管工作概覽

金管局在2016年共進行188次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍廣泛，包括認可機構的CAMEL評級、企業管治、業務運作及風險管理。金管局加強與認可機構董事局的聯繫，以強化銀行業的風險管治及企業文化。除與董事局或董事局委員會舉行會議外，亦另行與獨立非執行董事（獨立非執董）會面，就企業文化及風險管治事宜交換意見。金管局亦與認可機構及其外聘審計師舉行三方聯席會議。此外，金管局就認可機構的薪酬制度是否有助促進有效的風險管理進行評估。

在資本充足水平方面，金管局審視認可機構的資本計劃，包括其未來數年的資本目標，以便就2019年全面實施《巴塞爾協定三》緩衝資本作好準備。認可機構的償付能力壓力測試亦因應當前宏觀經濟環境作出改進。金管局又審慎評估各主要零售銀行的恢復計劃，並就需要改善的環節提出意見。

除了非現場審查工作外，金管局繼續以專題評估配合定期現場審查，而專題評估主要適用於被評定為較高風險的範疇。這種監管方法讓金管局更有效地調配監管資源，以應對認可機構所面對的各項新增及主要風險。金管局在2016年共進行377次現場審查及專題評估。這些審查與評估的重點仍是信用風險管理與監控，尤其涉及內地相關業務的信用風險；另一個重點是打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集監控措施。金管局又增加對流動性風險、業務操作風險及科技風險管理的現場審查及專題評估次數。年內專項審查小組亦對認可機構的證券、投資產品、保險及強制性公積金（強積金）相關業務進行現場審查。

表1載有金管局於2016年的監管工作概要。

# 信用風險的監管

# 信貸增長及資產質素

銀行貸款在2016年增長溫和。未償還貸款總額全年增加6.5%；2015年的增幅則為3.5%（表2）。由於客戶存款的增幅超過銀行貸款的增幅，整體貸存比率由2015年底的70.1%降至2016年底的68.4%。

表 2 貸款及墊款的增長

內地相關貸款總額在2016年底增加7%至35,640億港元（表3），其中包括在香港註冊的銀行設於內地的附屬公司入帳的5,450億港元貸款。

銀行業的資產質素在2016年維持穩健。儘管零售銀行的特定分類貸款比率由2015年底的0.69%微升至2016年底的0.72%，但仍遠低於2000年以來的長期平均水平2.4%。同期，整體銀行業的特定分類貸款比率由0.73%上升至0.85%。年內銀行業的內地相關貸款的資產質素呈相若走勢；同期，零售銀行這些貸款的特定分類貸款比率由0.78%微升至0.82%，整體銀行業的相關比率亦由一年前的0.77%微升至0.80%。

金管局投入大量監管資源，以確保認可機構繼續採用審慎的信貸審批標準，並維持有效的貸款分類及撥備制度。金管局在監管過程中亦特別關注認可機構對中國內地民營企業的風險承擔持續增加，以及為增加收益而投資於債務證券所引起的信用風險。此外，金管局就認可機構分銷高風險投資產品的信用風險管理進行專題評估。

# 物業按揭貸款

金管局繼續密切留意認可機構的物業貸款業務。住宅物業價格於2015年9月開始出現調整，但其後於2016年3月再度上升，全年上升8%。新造住宅物業按揭貸款的平均按揭成數，由2009年9月金管局尚未推出首輪物業貸款逆周期措施時的64%，降至2016年12月的51%。新造住宅物業按揭貸款的平均供款與入息比率亦由2010年8月首度推出供款與入息比率上限時的41%，降至2016年12月的34%（圖1）。

圖 1 新造住宅物業按揭貸款的平均按揭成數及供款與入息比率
金管局推出首輪物業貸款逆周期措施前推出供款與入息比率上限

根據金管局於2015年2月推出的第七輪逆周期措施，使用內部評級基準計算法計算信用風險資本要求的認可機構須將15%信用風險加權下限的應用，由新造按揭貸款延伸至整個住宅按揭貸款組合。這項規定於2016年6月生效。

年內有更多地產發展商向物業買家直接提供按揭貸款，其按揭成數往往高於金管局對認可機構實施審慎要求下許可的水平。金管局密切留意有關發展，並定期與認可機構溝通，以評估銀行有否繼續有效管理對地產發展商的風險承擔。此外，土地註冊處應金管局要求，同意向認可機構提供電子提示服務。使用這項服務的認可機構，當有其他按揭文書就其承按的物業交付土地註冊處辦理註冊時，會收到該處發出的電子提示訊息。這項服務將有助應對按揭借款人未有事先獲得承按認可機構同意下，擅自以同一物業借取額外按揭貸款的情況。土地註冊處已於2017年第1季推出電子提示服務。

# 業務操作及科技風險的監管

與其他國際金融中心一樣，香港面對的網絡威脅與日俱增。金管局於2016年接到認可機構通報發現未經授權股票交易及試圖入侵其支付系統的個案，並隨即採取行動應對這些攻擊造成的風險。金管局發出電子銀行服務提示，提醒公眾慎防網上股票交易騙案，並建議公眾採取預防措施。金管局又向認可機構發出通告，就進一步加強網上銀行服務監控可採取的保安措施提供指引。有關試圖入侵銀行支付系統的個案，金管局在香港首次發現相關個案時已提醒認可機構留意這類騙案，並在警方協助下說明這類騙案的犯案手法，以及要求認可機構在加強支付操作的監控措施時須顧及有關手法。

為進一步提升銀行體系應對網絡風險的能力，金管局於2016年5月推出網絡防衛計劃。此計劃由三項支柱組成，即網絡防衛評估框架、專業培訓計劃及網絡風險資訊共享平台（詳見「香港的國際金融中心地位」一章「金融科技促進辦公室」部分）。金管局在12月向認可機構發出通告，列載網絡防衛評估框架的實施時間表。

金融科技在銀行業的應用於2016年長足發展，多間認可機構推出新的金融科技產品，其中個人小額支付服務、非接觸式流動支付及生物認證這幾個範疇的發展尤為顯著。金管局在9月推出「金融科技監管沙盒」，讓認可機構能在受控環境中就其金融科技項目先作試行，而無需完全符合金管局的監管規定。有關安排讓認可機構在正式推出金融科技服務前，可及早收集真實數據及用戶意見，以便作出適當修改。截至2016年底，共有6項使用金融科技監管沙盒的申請獲批，有關的新金融科技產品涉及生物認證、證券交易及用於按揭估值的區塊鏈。金管局又在11月上調無需雙重認證的網上銀行個人小額支付服務的交易上限至每個帳戶每日5,000港元，以應付日益增加的簡便個人支付服務需求。

2016年發生多宗與物業相關的騙案，當中涉及騙徒假扮業主，試圖藉申請按揭貸款或出售有關物業謀取利益。雖然這些騙案並不涉及認可機構，但金管局仍與警方及香港銀行公會（銀行公會）緊密合作，就偵測及防止這些騙案在銀行業內發生向認可機構提供指引。年內金管局出版兩期《操作事故通訊》，與業界分享從認可機構發生過的操作事故中汲取的教訓。金管局亦對認可機構的業務操作風險管理制度、詐騙管理方法、信託╱託管業務操作及防範違規或未經授權交易活動的風險管理及監控措施進行現場審查及專題評估。

# 財資業務及流動性風險的監管

2016年發生數宗重大政治事件，引致金融市場在年內多次大幅波動。與此同時，美國利率繼續緩慢地正常化，聯邦公開市場委員會於12月決定調高聯邦基金利率，是全球金融危機以來的第二次。為應對這些政治事件作好準備，金管局與境外監管機構繼續保持緊密聯繫，並評估事件對香港銀行體系的影響，以及要求銀行保持警覺並加強其風險管理以應對不利的市場發展。

在流動性風險管理方面，金管局進行額外的流動性壓力測試，以評估銀行體系應對可能發生的嚴峻壓力情境的能力，並對認可機構作出跟進，以加強其應對能力。金管局在2015年針對利率風險管理進行一輪現場審查後，再進行額外的現場審查，以評估認可機構的市場風險管理，並要求在監控方面存有不足的認可機構作出糾正。

# 打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集活動

金管局的風險為本打擊洗錢監管包括現場審查及非現場審查（包括就特定事件與認可機構進行的監管聯繫），主要針對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險較高的範疇。審查內容涵蓋認可機構對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險的評估、風險為本方法的落實情況，以及交易監察與制裁合規的制度和程序。金管局的專項監管人員在2016年共進行17次現場審查及30次非現場審查。

在政策發展方面，金管局優先處理某些行業及人士在開立銀行帳戶方面遇到困難的情況，並發出指引與「常見問題」，以釐清若干客戶盡職審查的規定，以及金管局就風險為本方法的監管期望。與此同時，金管局繼續與業內公會緊密合作，發出指引以協助認可機構處理某些範疇的風險，例如貿易相關的洗錢活動。

# Banking System Stability

Despite the increase in global market risks and turbulence, the Hong Kong banking system remained sound in 2016. The HKMA strengthened its supervision of the risk governance frameworks of authorized institutions, as well as the effectiveness of their credit and liquidity risk management systems. In light of the increasing frequency of cyber attacks, the HKMA also enhanced its oversight of the technology risk management practices of authorized institutions. To implement the HKMA's commitment to combating financial crimes, the effectiveness of authorized institutions' measures to monitor money laundering and terrorist financing remains a key regulatory focus for the HKMA. In regulating the conduct of authorized institutions, the HKMA took concrete actions to promote customer-centric corporate culture and advance financial inclusion, as well as address difficulties faced by overseas small and medium-sized enterprises and startups in opening and maintaining bank accounts in Hong Kong. The HKMA also strengthened its supervision of the practices used by authorized institutions in selling investment and insurance products to further enhance customer protection.

In terms of regulatory policy, the HKMA has made significant progress in preparing Hong Kong for the implementation of international regulatory and accounting standards; this includes stabilising the net funding ratio, setting limits on large risk exposures, International Financial Reporting Standard 9, and the resolution framework under the Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance.

# 2016 Review

# Regulatory Work Overview

In 2016, the HKMA conducted 188 non-site reviews, covering a wide range, including CAMEL ratings of authorized institutions, corporate governance, business operations, and risk management. The HKMA strengthened its contact with the boards of directors of authorized institutions to enhance risk governance and corporate culture in the banking sector. In addition to holding meetings with the board of directors or its committees, the HKMA also met separately with independent non-executive directors (IneDs) to exchange opinions on corporate culture and risk governance matters. The HKMA also held trilateral joint meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors. Furthermore, the HKMA assessed whether the remuneration systems of authorized institutions help promote effective risk management.

In terms of capital adequacy levels, the HKMA reviews the capital plans of authorised institutions, including their capital targets for the next few years, to be well-prepared for the full implementation of Basel III buffer capital in 2019. Stress tests on the capital adequacy of authorised institutions have also been improved in response to the current macroeconomic environment. The HKMA also prudently assesses the recovery plans of major retail banks and provides feedback on areas needing improvement.

In addition to off-site reviews, the HKMA continues to complement regular on-site inspections with thematic assessments, which are primarily applied to higher-risk areas. This regulatory approach enables the HKMA to more effectively allocate regulatory resources to address the various new and key risks faced by authorized institutions. In 2016, the HKMA conducted a total of 377 on-site inspections and thematic assessments. The focus of these reviews and assessments remains on credit risk management and monitoring, particularly credit risks related to mainland China operations; another key focus is measures to combat money laundering and the monitoring of terrorist financing. The HKMA also increased the frequency of on-site inspections and thematic assessments related to liquidity risk, operational risk, and technology risk management. During the year, specialist review teams also conducted on-site inspections of authorized institutions' businesses related to securities, investment products, insurance, and the mandatory provident fund (MPF).

# Credit Risk Regulation

# Credit Growth and Asset Quality

Bank loans grew modestly in 2016. The total outstanding loans increased by 6.5% for the year; the growth rate in 2015 was 3.5% (Table 2). Due to the growth rate of customer deposits exceeding that of bank loans, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio decreased from 70.1% at the end of 2015 to 68.4% at the end of 2016.

Table 2: Growth of Loans and Advances

The total amount of related loans in Mainland China increased by 7% to 35,640 billion Hong Kong dollars at the end of 2016 (Table 3), which includes 5,450 billion Hong Kong dollars in loans recorded by subsidiaries established in the Mainland by banks registered in Hong Kong.

The asset quality of the banking sector remained sound in 2016. Despite the specific classification loan ratio for retail banks rising slightly from 0.69% at the end of 2015 to 0.72% at the end of 2016, it remained well below the long-term average of 2.4% since 2000. During the same period, the specific classification loan ratio for the overall banking sector rose from 0.73% to 0.85%. During the year, the asset quality of domestic-related loans in the banking sector showed a similar trend; during the same period, the specific classification loan ratio for these loans in retail banks rose slightly from 0.78% to 0.82%, while the corresponding ratio for the overall banking sector also rose slightly from 0.77% a year earlier to 0.80%.

The HKMA devotes significant regulatory resources to ensure that authorised institutions continue to adopt prudent credit approval standards and maintain effective loan classification and provisioning systems. The HKMA also pays special attention to the sustained increase in risk exposure of authorised institutions towards mainland China's private enterprises, as well as the credit risk arising from investments in debt securities aimed at increasing returns. In addition, the HKMA conducts thematic assessments on the credit risk management of authorised institutions in relation to the distribution of high-risk investment products.

# Property Mortgage Loans

The HKMA continues to closely monitor the property loan business of authorized institutions. Residential property prices began to adjust in September 2015, but rose again in March 2016, increasing by 8% for the year. The average loan-to-value (LTV) ratio for newly granted residential mortgage loans fell from 64% in September 2009, before the HKMA introduced its first round of countercyclical property loan measures, to 51% in December 2016. The average debt-to-income ratio for newly granted residential mortgage loans also declined from 41% in August 2010, when the HKMA first introduced a cap on debt-to-income ratios, to 34% in December 2016 (Chart 1).

Chart 1: Average loan-to-value (LTV) ratio and repayment-to-income ratio for newly granted residential property mortgage loans  
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority introduced a cap on repayment-to-income ratio before launching the first round of counter-cyclical property loan measures.

According to the seventh round of countercyclical measures introduced by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority in February 2015, authorized institutions using the internal ratings-based approach to calculate credit risk capital requirements must extend the application of the 15% lower bound for credit risk-weighted amounts from newly granted mortgage loans to the entire residential mortgage loan portfolio. This provision took effect in June 2016.

More property developers are directly providing mortgage loans to property buyers within the year, with their loan-to-value (LTV) ratios often exceeding the levels permitted under the HKMA's prudential requirements for authorized institutions. The HKMA is closely monitoring this development and regularly communicates with authorized institutions to assess whether banks continue to effectively manage the risk exposure related to property developers. Additionally, the Land Registry, at the request of the HKMA, has agreed to provide an electronic alert service to authorized institutions. Authorized institutions using this service will receive electronic alert messages from the Land Registry when other mortgage documents related to properties they have taken security over are submitted to the Land Registry for registration. This service will help address situations where mortgage borrowers take out additional mortgage loans on the same property without prior approval from the authorized institution taking security. The Land Registry launched the electronic alert service in the first quarter of 2017.

# Supervision of Business Operations and Technology Risks

Like other international financial centres, Hong Kong faces increasingly growing cyber threats. In 2016, the HKMA received reports from authorised institutions about cases involving unauthorised stock trading and attempts to infiltrate their payment systems, and immediately took action to address the risks posed by these attacks. The HKMA issued electronic banking service tips, reminding the public to be cautious of online stock trading scams and recommending that the public take preventive measures. The HKMA also issued notices to authorised institutions, providing guidance on security measures that could be taken to further strengthen the monitoring of online banking services. Regarding cases of attempts to infiltrate banking payment systems, the HKMA had already alerted authorised institutions to be vigilant about such scams when the first related case was identified in Hong Kong, and with the assistance of the police, explained the modus operandi of such scams, as well as required authorised institutions to take into account these methods when enhancing monitoring measures for payment operations.

To further enhance the banking system's capacity to cope with cybersecurity risks, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the Cybersecurity Defense Plan in May 2016. This plan comprises three pillars: the Cybersecurity Defense Assessment Framework, a professional training program, and a cybersecurity risk information sharing platform (see the section on the "Fintech Facilitation Office" in the chapter titled "Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre"). In December, the HKMA issued a notice to authorized institutions outlining the implementation timeline for the Cybersecurity Defense Assessment Framework.

The application of fintech in the banking sector made significant progress in 2016, with multiple authorized institutions launching new fintech products. Notably, developments in person-to-person small-value payment services, contactless mobile payments, and biometric authentication stood out. In September, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) introduced the "Fintech Regulatory Sandbox," allowing authorized institutions to conduct pilot trials of their fintech projects in a controlled environment without needing to fully comply with HKMA's regulatory requirements. This arrangement enables authorized institutions to collect real data and user feedback early on before officially launching their fintech services, facilitating appropriate modifications. As of the end of 2016, six applications for using the fintech regulatory sandbox were approved, involving new fintech products related to biometric authentication, securities trading, and blockchain technology for mortgage valuations. In November, the HKMA also increased the transaction limit for online banking person-to-person small-value payment services without requiring dual authentication to HK$5,000 per account daily, to meet the growing demand for convenient personal payment services.

In 2016, multiple fraud cases related to property occurred, involving fraudsters impersonating property owners attempting to gain benefits by applying for mortgage loans or selling the relevant properties. Although these fraud cases did not involve authorized institutions, the HKMA still closely cooperated with the police and the Hong Kong Bankers' Association (Banking Association) to provide guidance to authorized institutions on detecting and preventing these fraud cases within the banking sector. During the year, the HKMA published two issues of the "Operations Incident Communications," sharing lessons learned from operational incidents that occurred at authorized institutions with the industry. The HKMA also conducted on-site reviews and thematic assessments of authorized institutions' business operational risk management systems, fraud management methods, trust/custody business operations, and risk management and monitoring measures to prevent non-compliant or unauthorized transaction activities.

# Regulatory Oversight of Treasury Business and Liquidity Risk

In 2016, several major political events occurred, leading to multiple marked fluctuations in financial markets throughout the year. Meanwhile, US interest rates continued to slowly normalize, and the Federal Open Market Committee decided in December to raise the Federal Funds Rate, marking the second time since the global financial crisis. To be well-prepared to cope with these political events, the HKMA continues to maintain close contact with overseas regulatory authorities, assesses the impact of these events on the Hong Kong banking system, and requires banks to stay vigilant and strengthen their risk management to address adverse market developments.

In liquidity risk management, the HKMA conducted additional liquidity stress tests to assess the banking system's ability to cope with severe stress scenarios and carried out follow-up actions on authorized institutions to strengthen their capacity to respond. Following a round of on-site reviews in 2015 aimed at interest rate risk management, the HKMA conducted further additional on-site reviews to assess the market risk management of authorized institutions and required those with deficiencies in their monitoring to take corrective actions.

# Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Activities

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) risk-based anti-money laundering regulatory framework includes on-site reviews and off-site reviews (including regulatory liaison with authorized institutions regarding specific events), primarily targeting areas with higher money laundering and terrorist financing risks. The review content covers the authorized institutions' assessment of money laundering and terrorist financing risks, the implementation of risk-based approaches, as well as systems and procedures for transaction monitoring and sanctions compliance. In 2016, the HKMA's specialist regulatory staff conducted 17 on-site reviews and 30 off-site reviews.

In terms of policy development, the HKMA prioritizes addressing situations where certain industries and individuals encounter difficulties in opening bank accounts, and issues guidelines and "frequently asked questions" to clarify certain customer due diligence requirements, as well as the HKMA's regulatory expectations regarding the risk-based approach. Meanwhile, the HKMA continues to closely cooperate with industry associations, issuing guidelines to help authorized institutions manage risks in certain areas, such as money laundering activities related to trade.
